information:
The 2025 James Beard Awards ceremony is scheduled to take place on June 16, 2025, in Chicago. The James Beard Foundation has recently made efforts to enhance inclusivity and equity in its awards program. These changes include the introduction of new categories, such as Best New Bar, Outstanding Professional in Beverage Service, and Outstanding Professional in Cocktail Service, as well as a shift to a regional model for the Best Chef category.

Several women have been named as finalists for the 2025 James Beard Awards. Cassie Piuma of Sarma in Somerville, MA, is a finalist for the national award of Outstanding Chef. Other female finalists in regional categories include Sarah Thompson of Casa Playa in Las Vegas (Best Chef: Southwest), Amanda Shulman of Her Place Supper Club in Philadelphia (Best Chef: Mid-Atlantic), and Erin Miller of Urban Hearth in Cambridge (Best Chef: Northeast).

In the last ten award cycles for James Beard Outstanding Chef, women have won four times. Since 2020, the James Beard Foundation has implemented an equity initiative. Following this, the share of female winners in the regional Best Chef awards increased from approximately 30% before 2020 to around 55% in 2024. The winners of the Outstanding Chef award in 2023 (Rob Rubba) and 2024 (Michael Rafidi) were men.

forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: Approximately 20 days. The 2025 James Beard Awards ceremony is scheduled for June 16, 2025, and today is May 27, 2025.
forecast.status_quo_outcome: A man wins the 2025 James Beard Award for Outstanding Chef. The last two winners (2023 and 2024) were men, suggesting a recent trend toward male winners in this specific category.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: One of the male finalists for Outstanding Chef receives the award instead of Cassie Piuma. Given the competitive nature of this national award and that multiple chefs are typically nominated, the voting panel selects a male chef based on their culinary achievements and contributions to the industry.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Cassie Piuma of Sarma in Somerville, MA wins the Outstanding Chef award. The judging panel recognizes her exceptional culinary work, and the Foundation's equity initiatives translate into outcomes at the national award level, similar to the improvements seen in regional categories.
forecast.rationale: The historical base rate is crucial here: women have won 4 out of the last 10 Outstanding Chef awards (40%). However, there's a recent trend showing the last two consecutive winners were men, which might suggest momentum against a female winner, though two data points isn't a strong trend. The Foundation's equity initiatives since 2020 are notable - regional Best Chef awards showed dramatic improvement from 30% to 55% female winners. However, the Outstanding Chef award is a national, more prestigious category that may have different dynamics. Cassie Piuma being explicitly named as a finalist is significant and confirms a woman has a legitimate chance. Without knowing the total number of finalists or the voting mechanism details, I must rely heavily on the historical base rate. The 40% historical rate, combined with equity initiatives pushing upward and recent male winners pushing downward, suggests a probability in the 30-40% range. My forecast would increase if: (1) we knew Piuma was one of only 2-3 finalists, (2) there were credible reports of strong support for her candidacy, or (3) leaked voting indicated she was leading. My forecast would decrease if: (1) there were many male finalists with exceptional credentials, (2) insider information suggested male chefs were favored, or (3) we learned the equity initiatives had less impact on national awards.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will a woman win the 2025 James Beard Award for Outstanding Chef?

Question background:
[Here Are the 2025 James Beard Awards Restaurant, Chef, and Media Award Finalists](https://www.eater.com/24398769/2025-james-beard-awards-restaurant-chef-finalists)


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if a woman wins the 2025 James Beard Award for Outstanding Chef.




Your research assistant's report says:
The 2025 James Beard Awards ceremony is scheduled to take place on June 16, 2025, in Chicago. The James Beard Foundation has recently made efforts to enhance inclusivity and equity in its awards program. These changes include the introduction of new categories, such as Best New Bar, Outstanding Professional in Beverage Service, and Outstanding Professional in Cocktail Service, as well as a shift to a regional model for the Best Chef category.

Several women have been named as finalists for the 2025 James Beard Awards. Cassie Piuma of Sarma in Somerville, MA, is a finalist for the national award of Outstanding Chef. Other female finalists in regional categories include Sarah Thompson of Casa Playa in Las Vegas (Best Chef: Southwest), Amanda Shulman of Her Place Supper Club in Philadelphia (Best Chef: Mid-Atlantic), and Erin Miller of Urban Hearth in Cambridge (Best Chef: Northeast).

In the last ten award cycles for James Beard Outstanding Chef, women have won four times. Since 2020, the James Beard Foundation has implemented an equity initiative. Following this, the share of female winners in the regional Best Chef awards increased from approximately 30% before 2020 to around 55% in 2024. The winners of the Outstanding Chef award in 2023 (Rob Rubba) and 2024 (Michael Rafidi) were men.

Today is 2025-05-27.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
